posts.cooked:
Last year, our team used a naming system so that the drive team could figure out what each auto did. the 3 closest notes were notes A (closest to amp), B, and C (closest to podium) and then the midline notes were D,E,F,G, and H.

This year, this naming system will not work because there are so many more places to score, for example, on level 2 there are 12 total places.

if we tried to use a similar naming system to last year, for a 2 piece auto, we would end up with something like: L2S1R_L2S1L where L{number} represents the level, S{number} represents a side of the reef, and then the last letter of each position denoting left or right side. I think that this naming system will just end up being very confusing for the drive team, and so I was wondering if anyone has come up with a better naming system that allows me to specify which location on the reef will be scored on? This is important because if we start scoring multiple pieces, the names for the autos will get really long and confusing really fast.

I am posting this early in the season for two reasons. firstly, by the time our team gets to making autos, we will hopefully have a good naming convention to use. Secondly, if decided early, it will give other teams a chance to learn and potentially make whatever naming convention that is most easy to understand standard on their team as well, or at least be familiar with it. If we can come up with a standard, it would greatly improve the effectiveness of pre-match strategy discussions between teams as supposed to “we will score on the closest side on the left L2.”

so, with that being said, what are some ideas for naming systems? and, do you think that having a naming system become commonly accepted is a good idea?

also, if you find a reply with a naming system you like, please like it so that we can compile the general consensus and use the most liked system.

So far, from what I am seeing, I believe that it would be best for 2 naming systems. one for software, where it needs to be compact, and one for callouts, which is longer and a little more descriptive. for software and auto purposes, I think that using the naming system that first provided (see @Amicus1 ’s reply) for the branches and then a number to denote the level would be best, as something like H2 or A3 is very compact. for callouts, I think both @w4drone ’s (just being descriptive) and @jedgar6 ’s (using clock) reply are good ideas.

link_counts.title: How are you guys naming all of the reef posts?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
FIRST already gave the branches identifiers in the FMS . image 828×777 96.8 KB

image 828×777 96.8 KB

image 828×777 96.8 KB

Credit to 4481 for the cleaner chart.

was thinking about this, to me the obvious answer is either letter number them clockwise starting from the front, but i would probably personally prefer something like “L4, back left side, node 1”. In my experience, this type of callout is the nicest under pressure, i am terrible at the lettering/numbering systems under pressure, and this is the easiest to read back (which is always a good thing to do!)

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: We’ve been using clock numbers. So A is 1 o’clock. Then we say T1-4. Clock positions are far easier to judge quickly.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: A numbering scheme would be nice to introduce a natural parity to the left and right branches of each side of the hexagon. i.e. odd numbers are left, even numbers are right
so, for example, we could do H2_G2 to score at H level 2 and G level 2. I like this naming system.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: It might get a bit confusing with branch L
would {branchLetter}L{level} be better?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Possibly. I think there’s also a valid reason to use a different convention for software (prioritizing short and non-redundant) than for drive coaching callouts.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
w4drone:

“L4, back left side, node 1”. In my experience, this type of callout is the nicest under pressure,

I second a convention that leaves little room for ambiguity. My preference would be clarity over compactness, however this is achieved.

From the software side of things I have little preference, but it would probally be helpful for the same pattern for drive and software(e.g., [level, face, pipe] or [pipe-letter, level]).

Edit: If I had to pick something I would go with [pipe-letter, level]… it just makes sense.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked:
I am begging everyone in this thread to just use the naming system provided by FIRST (and shown in the very first response to OP) so we can all communicate sensibly at competitions, instead of inventing your own.

Edit: please let’s all try to avoid this situation standards_2x 1000×567 49.1 KB

standards_2x 1000×567 49.1 KB

standards_2x 1000×567 49.1 KB

posts.name: MARS_James
posts.cooked:
This is 100% how we are going to explain it to other teams:

“Our auto scores it’s preload on E4 then scores the next on D4 and keeps going in that direction” Is something we all understand

Internally, both in calling out in the match where to score next and how we are going to program it may be a little different as in the heat of the match remembering which Peg is J vs K and which button each corresponds to is something we want to avoid.

I agree. I have added another little paragraph at the bottom of my post to add a distinction between the two, as the software naming system is not going to be as easy to remember in the heat of a match.

posts.name: Jsteel
posts.cooked: As someone who has been in a lot of Alliance meetings, if you want your team to be an annoyance to others then use something other than FIRST ’s system.  That includes the Programmers, because invariably they are involved in Alliance discussions on Autos.  Just make it easy on yourself and everyone else (important).  Please use the FIRST established letters and levels.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Meetings fine.  Going to get messed up in the heat of competition, though.  We’ve spent our lives looking at clocks.  There’s a reason pilots use directions like “12 [o’clock] high” and “6 [o’clock] low”.  You immediately know what that means w/o requiring conscious thought.   Saying “[pole] G [level] 4” much less so.

posts.name: Pranay Thapa
posts.cooked:
fwiw, we have found that using the phonetic alphabet is useful for this game as B, D, and E all sound the same:

image 1002×1870 113 KB

image 1002×1870 113 KB

image 1002×1870 113 KB

Ex. Echo4, Bravo2, Foxtrot3, etc.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: We are using 1-6 for reef side, left middle right, and then L1-L4. We use this for our automated scoring interface our operator has on a touchscreen/tablet.
In the NATO phonetic alphabet, the spellings are “Alfa” and “Juliett” for whatever reason, while law enforcement uses “Alpha” and “Juliette”. See also: the above XKCD comic.

posts.name: Pranay Thapa
posts.cooked: We had that conversation aswell and came to the conclusion that as long as they (drive team) were using the same set it really didn’t matter (plus when spoken spelling doesn’t matter)

X# notation definitely the best.

An alternative phonetic set using animals. All are the same spoken speed & distinct VC \CVC sounds, using an elementary lexicon, and not sounding like numbers 1,2,3,4.

Letter Animals A Ant B Bear C Cow D Dog E Elk F Fox G Goat H Horse I Imp J Jack K Krill L Leech
